attributes.title: Baseline treatment
attributes.description: Treatment where self-reports are not available.

q1.value: Reporting Behavior in Teamwork: Baseline treatment

q2.value: Santiago Sanchez.pages, Maria Cubel, Ann- Kathrin Koessler, Robert Hoffmann

q3.value:
We want to study reporting about the own performance in teamwork interactions. 

We hypothesize two main reasons for lying: enhancing own image in front of others and inducing others to work harder for one’s own benefit. 

We want to study whether self-promotion through performance reports may enhance effort in teamwork or if, on the contrary, own effort and lies aimed to induce others to work harder are substitutes. 

The purpose of the treatment registered here is to measure performance in the baseline case where reports are not available.

q4.value:
The following hypotheses will be tested by comparing the treatment registered here with the analogous ones were self-reports are available and described in the attached document.

H1: Performance is higher when subjects have the opportunity to report their own performance and these reports are not verifiable.
H2a: Performance is higher when subjects have the opportunity to report their own performance in a teamwork task and these reports are not verifiable.
H2b: Performance is lower when subjects have the opportunity to report their own performance in a teamwork task and these reports are not verifiable.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The treatment registered here consists of two conditions. Each condition will be composed by six rounds. Each round will be composed by two phases, a ‘task’ phase where subjects will perform the “counting zeroes” task (Abeler et al. 2010), and an ‘information’ phase where subjects will be informed about their own performance. The two conditions will take place in the following order:
First, the ‘Individual’ condition, in which subjects will receive a piece rate payment per solved matrix. 
Second, the ‘Group Share’ condition, in which subjects will receive a fourth of the rate in ‘Individual’ per solved matrix in their group, including those solved by themselves.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
There is no data yet on the treatment registered here.
Data has been collected for treatments where we vary the informational conditions. We have not analysed or seen this data.

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the existing list of interested participants. Participants receive 3€ for participating, 2€ for answering the questionnaire and the amount they earn from the effort task. Participants must be students at Osnabrück University. There are no other inclusion or exclusion criteria.

q13.value: Our target is to recruit 80 students for the treatment. Because there are 6 rounds in each condition that yields 480 observations per condition.

q14.value: The sample size targeted is identical to the target size targeted for the variant of the treatment where participants can send reports about the own performance. The sample size was selected for that variant based on power calculations, as described in the attached document.

question.value:
Performance in the individual condition.
Performance in the Group Share condition.

Performance will be measured by the number of matrices attempted and solved under each condition.
In addition, we will run a questionnaire with questions on demographics, questionnaires on ‘grit’, socio-emotional skills, self-esteem and the Big Five personality traits. We will study through simple regressions whether individual performance is moderated by these factors.
OLS regressions on individual performance per round as dependent variable with treatment dummy (baseline vs self-report), round number and personal characteristics as controls.

q25.value: Abeler, Johannes, et al. “GIFT EXCHANGE AND WORKERS' FAIRNESS CONCERNS: WHEN EQUALITY IS UNFAIR.” Journal of the European Economic Association, vol. 8, no. 6, 2010, pp. 1299–1324.

attributes.title: Testing effects of progesterone and estradiol on disgust, food intake, mating, and anxiety

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Testing effects of progesterone and estradiol on disgust, food intake, mating, and anxiety.

sample.value: We will recruit 40 women, each of whom will participate in 21 diary sessions and three lab sessions.

analyses.value: For most analyses, multi-level models with random intercepts for participants will be used. More details are provided in the time-stamped document on OSF.

outliers.value: We will examine and identify outliers after data are collected. We will report all analyses with outliers excluded and included, and we will transparently discuss our justification for excluding outliers. All such decisions will be made before data are analyzed.

dependent.value: Dependent variables are listed in the time-stamped document on OSF.

hypothesis.value: We are testing the effects of within-woman changes in progesterone and estradiol on disgust (toward both pathogen and sexual stimuli), diet, anxiety, and mate preferences. Exhaustive details are provided in the time-stamped document on OSF.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: The Effect of Instagram Use on Well-Being and Breakup Adjustment
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
•	Experimental condition: (between-groups design): Ex-Partner - Instagram condition, Acquaintance - Instagram condition, Geometric Shapes - Instagram condition 
•	Attachment Style

question2b.value:
•	Positive and negative affect
•	Extent of social comparison
•	Social comparison-based emotions 
•	Breakup adjustment (sexual desire for ex-partner, breakup distress)
•	Jealousy 
•	Manipulation check 1: how well do they know person who created Instagram account, closeness to person, visibility of person’s page, how much information was revealed on Instagram)
•	Manipulation check 2: how much did looking at the person’s Instagram page make them miss ex-partner, think of ex’s relationships with others, feel close to ex, feel familiar with details of ex’s life

question3b.value:
•	Social Comparison Orientation
•	Self-esteem
•	Neuroticism
•	Avoidant attachment
•	Gender
•	Who initiated the breakup (my partner did, I did/we both did)
•	Current involvement in a relationship (yes/no)
•	Frequency of Instagram use (average time spent per day)
•	Currently following ex-partner on Instagram (yes/no)

question10b.value: Procedure: The participants will start with an online survey on the computer that measures social comparison orientation, neuroticism, self-esteem, and attachment style. Approximately half-way through the survey, the participants would be asked to log in to their Instagram account on the computer. The participants would be randomly assigned to spend 2 minutes looking at the Instagram feed of either a former romantic partner, an acquaintance, or a neutral Instagram page of geometric patterns. The participants would continue working through the rest of the online survey which would measure (1) manipulation check questions 1; (2) positive and negative affect and social comparison behavior and emotions; (3) manipulation check questions 2, breakup adjustment (breakup distress, sexual desire for ex), and jealousy towards the ex-partner. (2) and (3) will be presented in a counterbalanced order, and the scales within each of (2) and (3) will be presented in a random order. After completing these key dependent variables, participants then complete questions about their ex-partner and break-up, their current relationship status, their Instagram activity, and demographic questions. Participants who looked at an acquaintance’s page answer additional questions about the acquaintance (e.g., their relationship with the acquaintance, gender identity of acquaintance).

question4b.value:
Participants must be: 
1. Undergraduate student age 18 and over from researcher's university 
2. A registered user of Instagram 
3. Someone who has experienced a relationship breakup within the last 2 years. This breakup should be with someone with whom they were emotionally involved (not a breakup that occurred after only one or two dates), and someone whose Instagram page they have seen at least once. 
4. Must not be currently blocked from viewing ex-partner’s Instagram page.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from the SONA participant pool of a psychology department at a university in Canada. Participants will receive 0.5 credit as an incentive for completing the study.

question6b.value: Participants will consist of 150 university students recruited from SONA. This sample size is sufficient to detect a medium effect size (f = .26) at 80% power, α = 0.05, through a one-way ANOVA. Participants will be randomly assigned in equal numbers to the ex-romantic partner group, acquaintance group, or a neutral condition group (geometric shapes).

question7b.value: We will stop collecting data once we have recruited 150 participants (final N after exclusions).

question8b.value:
•	We will remove duplicates, overly consistent responses (e.g., indicating “1” for everything), cases with more than 10% missing data, cases that show a pattern of nonsense answers (e.g., answering “daklfsjyhi” to qualitative questions)
•	Exclude participants who take less than 5 minutes and more than 60 minutes to complete the survey
•	Two attention-check questions will be embedded in the survey. Participants who do not correctly answer both questions will be excluded.
•	Exclude participants who indicate that their breakup occurred more than 2 years ago
•	Exclude participants who indicate that they do not use Instagram
•	Will not exclude participants on the basis of any other outlier data

question9b.value: We are not setting any fail-safe levels of exclusions for stopping, altering, or restarting the study.

question8c.value: If an item reduces Cronbach’s alpha to less than .50, it will be deleted from the scale.

question10c.value: Tolerance/VIF will be examined to see if predictors in multiple regressions show too much multicollinearity. If they do, we will conduct PAF (direct oblimin rotation) to reduce the correlated predictors into a single variable.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1: Manipulation check 1. (a) Participants in the Ex-Partner condition will report that they know the person more whose Instagram page they looked at and feel closer to them than participants in the Acquaintance and Geometric (neutral control) conditions. (b) Acquaintance > Geometric for the same manipulation check variables.

Hypothesis 2: Manipulation check 2. Participants in the Ex-Partner condition will report that the manipulation made them miss their ex-partner more, think about their ex’s relationships with other people more, feel closer to their ex-partner, and feel more familiar with the details of their ex-partner’s life than participants in the Acquaintance and Geometric (neutral control) conditions. 

Hypothesis 3: (a) Participants in the Ex-Partner condition will report more negative affect and jealousy, and less positive affect and breakup adjustment, than participants in the two control conditions. (b) Participants in the Acquaintance condition will report more negative affect and less positive affect than participants in the Geometric control condition. 

Hypothesis 4(a): Anxious attachment will be positively associated with negative affect and jealousy, and negatively associated with positive affect and breakup adjustment.

Hypothesis 4(b): Anxious attachment x condition: Participants in the Ex-Partner condition who are higher in anxious attachment will report more negative affect, less positive affect, poorer breakup adjustment, and more jealousy compared to participants in this condition who are lower in anxious attachment, and compared to participants higher in anxiety in the other two conditions.

Hypothesis 5(a): Relative to participants in the Geometric control condition, participants in the Acquaintance condition will report (a) more envy, depression, and worry when they compared themselves to the person they looked at on Instagram, and (b) more negative affect and less positive affect. 

Hypothesis 5(b): Condition x social comparison orientation: Relative to participants low in social comparison orientation, participants in the Acquaintance condition who are high in social comparison orientation will report even more envy, depression, and worry when they compared themselves to the person they looked at on Instagram, and even more negative affect and less positive affect.

question5a.value: Attachment theory for main effects of anxiety and interactions of anxiety with condition

question1c.value: For all of the following analyses, variables will be calculated as mean scores across all of the items included in each scale. Breakup adjustment will be a composite variable consisting of breakup distress and sexual desire for the ex-partner (each reverse-scored, standardized, then averaged together so that higher scores indicates higher breakup adjustment).

question2c.value:
Hypotheses 1 and 2:

One-way ANOVAs will test the effect of condition on each of these DVs. If the one-way ANOVAs are significant, Bonferonni-corrected pairwise comparisons will be conducted with t-tests.

question3c.value:
Hypotheses 1 and 2:

Predictors: condition
Covariates: none
DVs: know the person, feel close to person, miss ex-partner, think about ex’s relationships, feel close to ex, familiarity with details of ex’s life

question1c.value: See above for details about variable calcuation

question2c.value: Hypothesis 5 will be tested with hierarchical multiple regression analysis (one for each DV).

question3c.value:
Predictors: Step 1: social comparison orientation; two dummy coded variables (a) Ex-Partner (0) vs Acquaintance (1); (b) and Ex-Partner (0) vs Geometric Control (1). 
Step 2: interactions of social comparison orientation with dummy code 1 and dummy code 2.
Covariates: (entered in Step 3) self-esteem, neuroticism, avoidant and anxious attachment, gender, who initiated the breakup, current involvement, frequency of Instagram use, currently following ex on Instagram.
DVs: negative affect, positive affect, negative social comparison emotions (envy, depression, worry)

question4c.value: Self-esteem, neuroticism, and attachment variables might all be associated with social comparison orientation.

question1c.value: See above for calculation of variables

question2c.value: Hypotheses 3-4 will be tested with hierarchical multiple regression analysis (one for each DV). We will also use these models to test the four manipulation check 2 variables on an exploratory basis.

question3c.value:
Hypotheses 3-4:

Predictors: Step 1: attachment anxiety; two dummy coded variables (a) Ex-Partner (0) vs Acquaintance (1); (b) and Ex-Partner (0) vs Geometric Control (1). Step 2: interactions of attachment anxiety with dummy code 1 and dummy code 2.
Covariates: (entered in Step 3) self-esteem, neuroticism, avoidant attachment, gender, who initiated the breakup, current involvement, frequency of Instagram use, currently following ex on Instagram.
DVs: negative affect, positive affect, breakup adjustment, jealousy, each of the four manipulation check variables

question4c.value: Self-esteem and neuroticism tend to be associated with attachment anxiety

attributes.title: Are randomized trials testing anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease informed by previous relevant trials and systematic reviews? A meta-epidemiological study.

q1.value: Are randomized trials testing anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease informed by previous relevant trials and systematic reviews? A meta-epidemiological study.

q2.value: Charitini Stavropoulou, Stefano Brini, Shashivadan Hirani, john Ioannidis

q3.value: Despite several decades of research efforts and billions of dollars spent on Alzheimer’s disease (AD), trials have been unsuccessful in discovering a treatment or cure (Cummings, Morstorf and Zhong, 2014). One of the hypotheses that has long remained the central focus of researchers in the area is that the neurodegeneration in AD may be caused by deposition of beta-amyloids, the fragment of a protein that can accumulate in plaques in brain tissue (Hardy and Higgins, 1992). Since the beta-amyloids hypothesis was first proposed almost three decades ago, a number of clinical trials have been conducted around pharmacotherapies that can modify the pathological course of AD by affecting beta-amyloid levels in the blood or brain (Mangialasche, Solomon, Winblad, Mecocci and Kivipelto, 2010; Mullane and Williams, 2013). However, trials testing the effects of amyloid-centric therapies so far have shown no major effects on clinical symptoms and do not seem to modify the underlying pathogenic processes (Karran and Hardy, 2014; Mangialasche et al., 2010; Mullane and Williams, 2013). Given the lack of success in establishing a link between beta-amyloids and a treatment for AD, it is timely to explore how this field of research has used prior empirical knowledge when planning new trials.

q4.value: The aim of this paper is to explore whether trials testing the effects of anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer Disease cite previous relevant systematic reviews, meta-analyses or randomized trials in their study.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will conduct a meta-epidemiological study on randomized trials testing anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Some priliminary searches have been conducted using different inclusion and exclusion criteria and different search strategies.

question.value:
Eligibility criteria:
We will search for randomized trials testing anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease that meet the following inclusion criteria:
-	Male or female adults, diagnosed according to the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke and the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association or other standard diagnostic tools with or without support of biomarkers of AD.
-	Intervention studies with prospective random allocation to two or more groups including one with an active eligible therapy 
-	Studies published between 1st January 1992 (the year the beta-amyloids hypothesis for AD was first proposed (Hardy and Higgins, 1992)) to 31st December 2019.
-	Studies published in English
We will exclude trials with the following characteristics:
-	Participants diagnosed with any other form of dementia; participants with mild cognitive impairment; healthy participants. Animal or in vitro studies.
-	Behavioural or psycho-social interventions such as physical exercise, dieting, etc and other pharmacological interventions not including anti-amyloid therapies.
-	Any study other than intervention studies such as observational studies, editorials, case studies, non-peer-reviewed studies, short reports, news, grey literature, research letters, correspondence sections

Data sources:
We will search MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, The Cochrane Library, and Web of Science. We will cross check the reference list of eligible studies. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses cited by the retrieved eligible published randomized trials will be searched to identify if there are any other eligible randomized trials that were missed by the other searches. Key terms will include: Alzheimer Disease/ OR alzheimers.ab. AND Amyloid/ or Amyloid beta-Peptides/ or Amyloid beta-Protein Precursor/ OR (beta amyloid or amyloidosis or amyloid beta protein or amyloid beta peptide or amyloid plaques).ab. AND (adaptive clinical trial or clinical study or clinical trial, all or clinical trial, phase i or clinical trial, phase ii or clinical trial, phase iii or clinical trial, phase iv or clinical trial protocol or clinical trial protocols as topic or clinical trial or controlled clinical trial or multicentre/multicenter study or pragmatic clinical trial or randomized controlled trial).

We will also search clinicaltrials.gov to identify registered trials have been published but had not been retrieved by our previous searches. We will search for: INFLECT EXACT "Completed" [OVERALL-STATUS] AND INFLECT EXACT "Interventional" [STUDY-TYPES] AND Alzheimer Disease [DISEASE] AND (Beta-amyloid plaque OR beta-amyloid OR amyloid OR amyloidosis OR amyloid beta-Peptides OR amyloid beta-protein precursor OR amyloid beta protein) [OUTCOME] AND INFLECT EXACT ( "Adult") [AGE-GROUP].

CS will be reviewing the applying eligibility criteria and selecting studies for inclusion in the meta-epidemiologic study. Two more researchers (SB and SH) will independently double screen decisions. Any disagreements will be discussed among CS, SB and SH to seek agreement.

q13.value: There is no prespecified sample size, as we will include all eligible studies.

question.value:
We will be extracting the following information:
•	Study design and methodology; participant demographics; numbers of systematic reviews and meta-analysis of randomized trials of anti-amyloid interventions in AD and/or randomized controlled trials of AD that are amyloid-focused cited in introduction, methods and discussion; other systematic reviews/meta-analyses, other randomized trials and other type of studies (such as animal studies, opinion papers etc) cited in the introduction of the study.
•	For each systematic review and/or meta-analysis cited, we will download the full text and identify which relevant trials of the same anti-amyloid intervention are cited.  
•	Version 2 of the Cochrane risk of bias tool (RoB 2) will be used to assess risk of bias among the included randomized trials. 

CS will extract data and will perform the risk of bias assessment. SB and SH will double-check the extracted data and risk of bias assessment and will discuss disagreements.

The results will be synthesized in the following way:
•	We will report the number of relevant systematic reviews and meta-analyses of randomized trials and relevant randomized trials in the introduction, methods and discussion of the study.
•	For each eligible trial, we will record how many of the previously published trials on the same intervention (i.e. published until the year preceding the publication) have been taken into account a) by citing a systematic review and/or meta-analysis that cites them, b) by citing the trial directly, or c) either option.   
•	We will report other systematic reviews/meta-analyses, other randomized trials and other type of studies (such as animal studies, opinion papers etc.) cited in the introduction of the study to justify the rationale for exploring the role of beta-amyloids in AD.

q25.value:
References:
Cummings, J. L., Morstorf, T., & Zhong, K. (2014). Alzheimer’s disease drug-development pipeline: few candidates, frequent failures. Alzheimer's research & therapy, 6(4), 37. 
Hardy, J.A, Higgins, G.A. (1992) Alzheimer’s disease: the amyloid cascade hypothesis. Science, 256(5054), 184-185.
Karran, E., & Hardy, J. (2014). A critique of the drug discovery and phase 3 clinical programs targeting the amyloid hypothesis for Alzheimer disease. Annals of neurology, 76(2), 185-205. 
Mangialasche, F., Solomon, A., Winblad, B., Mecocci, P., & Kivipelto, M. (2010). Alzheimer's disease: clinical trials and drug development. The Lancet Neurology, 9(7), 702-716. 
Mullane, K., & Williams, M. (2013). Alzheimer's therapeutics: continued clinical failures question the validity of the amyloid hypothesis—but what lies beyond? Biochemical pharmacology, 85(3), 289-305.

registration_responses.q1: Are randomized trials testing anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease informed by previous relevant trials and systematic reviews? A meta-epidemiological study.
registration_responses.q2: Charitini Stavropoulou, Stefano Brini, Shashivadan Hirani, john Ioannidis
registration_responses.q3: Despite several decades of research efforts and billions of dollars spent on Alzheimer’s disease (AD), trials have been unsuccessful in discovering a treatment or cure (Cummings, Morstorf and Zhong, 2014). One of the hypotheses that has long remained the central focus of researchers in the area is that the neurodegeneration in AD may be caused by deposition of beta-amyloids, the fragment of a protein that can accumulate in plaques in brain tissue (Hardy and Higgins, 1992). Since the beta-amyloids hypothesis was first proposed almost three decades ago, a number of clinical trials have been conducted around pharmacotherapies that can modify the pathological course of AD by affecting beta-amyloid levels in the blood or brain (Mangialasche, Solomon, Winblad, Mecocci and Kivipelto, 2010; Mullane and Williams, 2013). However, trials testing the effects of amyloid-centric therapies so far have shown no major effects on clinical symptoms and do not seem to modify the underlying pathogenic processes (Karran and Hardy, 2014; Mangialasche et al., 2010; Mullane and Williams, 2013). Given the lack of success in establishing a link between beta-amyloids and a treatment for AD, it is timely to explore how this field of research has used prior empirical knowledge when planning new trials.
registration_responses.q4: The aim of this paper is to explore whether trials testing the effects of anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer Disease cite previous relevant systematic reviews, meta-analyses or randomized trials in their study.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Some priliminary searches have been conducted using different inclusion and exclusion criteria and different search strategies.
registration_responses.q13: There is no prespecified sample size, as we will include all eligible studies.
registration_responses.q25:
References:
Cummings, J. L., Morstorf, T., & Zhong, K. (2014). Alzheimer’s disease drug-development pipeline: few candidates, frequent failures. Alzheimer's research & therapy, 6(4), 37. 
Hardy, J.A, Higgins, G.A. (1992) Alzheimer’s disease: the amyloid cascade hypothesis. Science, 256(5054), 184-185.
Karran, E., & Hardy, J. (2014). A critique of the drug discovery and phase 3 clinical programs targeting the amyloid hypothesis for Alzheimer disease. Annals of neurology, 76(2), 185-205. 
Mangialasche, F., Solomon, A., Winblad, B., Mecocci, P., & Kivipelto, M. (2010). Alzheimer's disease: clinical trials and drug development. The Lancet Neurology, 9(7), 702-716. 
Mullane, K., & Williams, M. (2013). Alzheimer's therapeutics: continued clinical failures question the validity of the amyloid hypothesis—but what lies beyond? Biochemical pharmacology, 85(3), 289-305.
registration_responses.q8.question: We will conduct a meta-epidemiological study on randomized trials testing anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Eligibility criteria:
We will search for randomized trials testing anti-amyloid interventions in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease that meet the following inclusion criteria:
-	Male or female adults, diagnosed according to the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke and the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association or other standard diagnostic tools with or without support of biomarkers of AD.
-	Intervention studies with prospective random allocation to two or more groups including one with an active eligible therapy 
-	Studies published between 1st January 1992 (the year the beta-amyloids hypothesis for AD was first proposed (Hardy and Higgins, 1992)) to 31st December 2019.
-	Studies published in English
We will exclude trials with the following characteristics:
-	Participants diagnosed with any other form of dementia; participants with mild cognitive impairment; healthy participants. Animal or in vitro studies.
-	Behavioural or psycho-social interventions such as physical exercise, dieting, etc and other pharmacological interventions not including anti-amyloid therapies.
-	Any study other than intervention studies such as observational studies, editorials, case studies, non-peer-reviewed studies, short reports, news, grey literature, research letters, correspondence sections

Data sources:
We will search MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, The Cochrane Library, and Web of Science. We will cross check the reference list of eligible studies. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses cited by the retrieved eligible published randomized trials will be searched to identify if there are any other eligible randomized trials that were missed by the other searches. Key terms will include: Alzheimer Disease/ OR alzheimers.ab. AND Amyloid/ or Amyloid beta-Peptides/ or Amyloid beta-Protein Precursor/ OR (beta amyloid or amyloidosis or amyloid beta protein or amyloid beta peptide or amyloid plaques).ab. AND (adaptive clinical trial or clinical study or clinical trial, all or clinical trial, phase i or clinical trial, phase ii or clinical trial, phase iii or clinical trial, phase iv or clinical trial protocol or clinical trial protocols as topic or clinical trial or controlled clinical trial or multicentre/multicenter study or pragmatic clinical trial or randomized controlled trial).

We will also search clinicaltrials.gov to identify registered trials have been published but had not been retrieved by our previous searches. We will search for: INFLECT EXACT "Completed" [OVERALL-STATUS] AND INFLECT EXACT "Interventional" [STUDY-TYPES] AND Alzheimer Disease [DISEASE] AND (Beta-amyloid plaque OR beta-amyloid OR amyloid OR amyloidosis OR amyloid beta-Peptides OR amyloid beta-protein precursor OR amyloid beta protein) [OUTCOME] AND INFLECT EXACT ( "Adult") [AGE-GROUP].

CS will be reviewing the applying eligibility criteria and selecting studies for inclusion in the meta-epidemiologic study. Two more researchers (SB and SH) will independently double screen decisions. Any disagreements will be discussed among CS, SB and SH to seek agreement.

•	For each systematic review and/or meta-analysis cited, we will download the full text and identify which relevant trials of the same anti-amyloid intervention are cited.  
•	Version 2 of the Cochrane risk of bias tool (RoB 2) will be used to assess risk of bias among the included randomized trials. 

CS will extract data and will perform the risk of bias assessment. SB and SH will double-check the extracted data and risk of bias assessment and will discuss disagreements.

•	For each eligible trial, we will record how many of the previously published trials on the same intervention (i.e. published until the year preceding the publication) have been taken into account a) by citing a systematic review and/or meta-analysis that cites them, b) by citing the trial directly, or c) either option.   
•	We will report other systematic reviews/meta-analyses, other randomized trials and other type of studies (such as animal studies, opinion papers etc.) cited in the introduction of the study to justify the rationale for exploring the role of beta-amyloids in AD.

attributes.title: Social Contexts and Highly and Minimally Processed Food Intake

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Social Contexts and Highly and Minimally Processed Food Intake Study Description

other.value:
Exploratory questions:
-Generally, when you are eating WITH YOUR FAMILY, how many family members are you eating with?
-Generally, when you are eating WITH YOUR FRIEND(S), how many friends are you eating with?
-Generally, when you are eating WITH YOUR COWORKER(S), how many coworkers are you eating with?
-Would you say that any of the following is impacting your diet in a NEGATIVE way? Please select as many as apply (Eating alone, Eating with your friend(s), Eating with your coworker(s), Eating with your romantic partner(s), Eating with your child/children, Eating with your family, None of the above)
-Would you say that any of the following is impacting your diet in a POSITIVE way? Please select as many as apply (Eating alone, Eating with your friend(s), Eating with your coworker(s), Eating with your romantic partner(s), Eating with your child/children, Eating with your family, None of the above)

sample.value: Qualtrics will recruit 750 participants from traditional, actively managed, double-opt-in market research panels (including website intercept recruitment, member referrals, targeted email lists, gaming sites, customer loyalty web portals, permission-based networks, and social media, etc.). Based on available research funds, this sample size is the greatest number of participants that can be collected through the Qualtrics mechanism.

analyses.value: All variables will be assessed for normality (i.e., skew, kurtosis). Transformations (e.g., natural log transformation) will be considered for non-normal variables (i.e., skew greater than |1|, kurtosis greater than |3|). Repeated Measures Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) will be conducted on (1) frequency reports and (2) on types of food reports. Co-eater status (romantic partners vs. children vs. family vs. friends vs. coworkers vs. alone) will be the within-subjects factor. Post-hoc LSD tests will be used for pairwise comparisons. Bivariate correlations will be conducted between demographic factors and (1) frequency reports and (2) types of food reports. Categorical demographic factors will be dummy coded.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from analysis if at lease one of the following criteria is met:
(1) Qualtrics determines the participant failed a quality check 
(2) The participant reports improbable values for adult height and weight
(3) The participant does not follow study instructions

dependent.value:
Main questions:
Weekdays:
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR ROMANTIC PARTNER(S)? (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating WITH YOUR ROMANTIC PARTNER(S) in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR CHILD/CHILDREN? (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating WITH YOUR CHILD/CHILDREN in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR FAMILY [i.e., family such as your mother, father, brother, sister, grandmother, grandfather, aunt, uncle, cousins; please do NOT include your romantic partner(s) or child/children]? (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating WITH YOUR FAMILY in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)

Please answer this question in reference to friends who are not also coworkers, romantic partners, children, and/or family. (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)

-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR COWORKER(S)? -Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL week (WEEKDAYS ONLY), about how much of that time are you eating ALONE? (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)

Weekends:

-When you are eating WITH YOUR ROMANTIC PARTNER(S) in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR CHILD/CHILDREN? (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)

(Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating WITH YOUR FAMILY in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR FRIEND(S)? Please answer this question in reference to friends who are not also coworkers, romantic partners, children, and/or family. (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating WITH YOUR FRIEND(S) in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR COWORKER(S)? Please answer this question in reference to coworkers who are not also friends, romantic partners, children, and/or family. (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating WITH YOUR COWORKER(S) in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), about how much of that time are you eating ALONE? (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating ALONE in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)

Demographics: 
-Please indicate your household size (i.e., the number of people permanently living in your home including you so the lowest possible number entered should be 1).
-What is the HIGHEST level of education that you have completed (Less than high school, High school graduate, Some college, Associate degree, Bachelors degree, Advanced degree)?
-What is your household income (Less than $20,000, $20,000-44,999, $45,000-139,999, $140,000-149,999, $150,000-199,999, $200,000 or greater)?
-What is your height, feet wise? (Ex: If you are 5 feet, 3 inches, select 5)
-What is your height, inches wise? (Ex: If you are 5 feet, 3 inches, select 3; If you are exactly 5 feet, select 0)
-How much do you weigh, in pounds? (Ex: If you are 250 lbs., type 250 in the blank below)
-How old are you, in years? (Ex: If you are 29 years old, type 29 in the blank below)
-What biological sex were you assigned at birth (Male, Female)?
-Which term BEST describes your gender (Man, Woman, Trans, Gender fluid)? 
-Which terms BEST describe your race/ethnicity (Native American or Alaska Native, Asian, Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, Black or African American, White, Hispanic/Latinx)?

conditions.value: This is a non-experimental study with no conditions.

hypothesis.value:
The main purposes of this study include: (1) comparing how frequently U.S. Americans report eating with certain co-eaters (i.e., romantic partners, children, friends, coworkers, and family) and eating alone, and (2) comparing what types of foods (minimally or highly processed) U.S. Americans report eating when with certain co-eaters and when alone. Given longstanding literature that eating patterns differ greatly between weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans will report on these behaviors separately for weekdays and weekend days. In addition, demographic data (i.e., household size, age, sex, race/ethnicity, BMI, education, and income) will be collected to test for associations with patterns of these behaviors. 

Hypotheses: 
(1)
-On weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans will report eating more frequently with romantic partners, children, family, and alone compared to eating with friends and coworkers.
-On weekdays and weekend days, single- versus multiple-household-member U.S. Americans  will report more frequently eating alone. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, older U.S. Americans will report eating more frequently with romantic partners, children, and family. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, younger U.S. Americans will report eating more frequently with friends. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, Hispanic/Latinx U.S. Americans compared to other race/ethnic groups will report eating more frequently with romantic partners, children, family, and friends.
-There are no other a priori hypotheses regarding how frequently U.S. Americans report they eat with co-eaters and alone. 
(2)
-On weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans will report eating more highly processed foods when with friends and alone compared to when eating with romantic partners, children, family, and coworkers. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans with greater BMI will report eating more highly processed foods when alone. 
-There are no other a priori hypotheses regarding what types of foods (minimally or highly processed) U.S. Americans report eating when with co-eaters and when alone.

-When you are eating WITH YOUR FRIEND(S) in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), about how much of that time are you eating WITH YOUR COWORKER(S)? Please answer this question in reference to coworkers who are not also friends, romantic partners, children, and/or family. (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating WITH YOUR COWORKER(S) in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)
-Of the time you spend eating in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), about how much of that time are you eating ALONE? (Slider answer, 0 = None of that time spent eating with... to 100 = All of that time spent eating with...)
-When you are eating ALONE in a TYPICAL weekend (SATURDAY AND SUNDAY), which of the following best describes your diet: (Slider answer, 0 = All HEALTHY food to 100 = All JUNK food)

Demographics: 
-Please indicate your household size (i.e., the number of people permanently living in your home including you so the lowest possible number entered should be 1).
-What is the HIGHEST level of education that you have completed (Less than high school, High school graduate, Some college, Associate degree, Bachelors degree, Advanced degree)?
-What is your household income (Less than $20,000, $20,000-44,999, $45,000-139,999, $140,000-149,999, $150,000-199,999, $200,000 or greater)?
-What is your height, feet wise? (Ex: If you are 5 feet, 3 inches, select 5)
-What is your height, inches wise? (Ex: If you are 5 feet, 3 inches, select 3; If you are exactly 5 feet, select 0)
-How much do you weigh, in pounds? (Ex: If you are 250 lbs., type 250 in the blank below)
-How old are you, in years? (Ex: If you are 29 years old, type 29 in the blank below)
-What biological sex were you assigned at birth (Male, Female)?
-Which term BEST describes your gender (Man, Woman, Trans, Gender fluid)? 
-Which terms BEST describe your race/ethnicity (Native American or Alaska Native, Asian, Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, Black or African American, White, Hispanic/Latinx)?
registration_responses.conditions: This is a non-experimental study with no conditions.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The main purposes of this study include: (1) comparing how frequently U.S. Americans report eating with certain co-eaters (i.e., romantic partners, children, friends, coworkers, and family) and eating alone, and (2) comparing what types of foods (minimally or highly processed) U.S. Americans report eating when with certain co-eaters and when alone. Given longstanding literature that eating patterns differ greatly between weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans will report on these behaviors separately for weekdays and weekend days. In addition, demographic data (i.e., household size, age, sex, race/ethnicity, BMI, education, and income) will be collected to test for associations with patterns of these behaviors. 

Hypotheses: 
(1)
-On weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans will report eating more frequently with romantic partners, children, family, and alone compared to eating with friends and coworkers.
-On weekdays and weekend days, single- versus multiple-household-member U.S. Americans  will report more frequently eating alone. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, older U.S. Americans will report eating more frequently with romantic partners, children, and family. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, younger U.S. Americans will report eating more frequently with friends. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, Hispanic/Latinx U.S. Americans compared to other race/ethnic groups will report eating more frequently with romantic partners, children, family, and friends.
-There are no other a priori hypotheses regarding how frequently U.S. Americans report they eat with co-eaters and alone. 
(2)
-On weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans will report eating more highly processed foods when with friends and alone compared to when eating with romantic partners, children, family, and coworkers. 
-On weekdays and weekend days, U.S. Americans with greater BMI will report eating more highly processed foods when alone. 
-There are no other a priori hypotheses regarding what types of foods (minimally or highly processed) U.S. Americans report eating when with co-eaters and when alone.

attributes.title: Impact of corporate commitments to source cage-free eggs on layer hen housing

summary.value:
Over the last decade, hundreds of companies around the world have committed to source cage-free eggs by 2025 or earlier. Commitments sometimes result from conversation with groups advocating to improve the treatment of animals, as cage-free housing is widely believed to provide better welfare for egg-laying hens. When conversation does not work, advocacy groups may run a campaign of public pressure, including protests or shaming in the media, which usually leads to a commitment. 

In this preregistration, we describe a detailed plan to use data from many countries on the share of hens living cage-free to understand the effect of cage-free commitments. We expect that commitments will shift the industry from caged to cage-free housing for hens. To test this, we will look at data from before and after commitments were made and in countries with and without commitments. We will also consider other factors, like changes in the law and illnesses that kill hens, that could affect how they are housed. We suspect that commitments and housing affect each other, so we will use advocacy groups' campaigns as a statistical tool to further clarify the cause-and-effect relationship. When we complete the planned study, it will provide thorough evidence on the impact of cage-free commitments, which might be useful to advocacy groups, companies making commitments, and the egg industry.

In this preregistration, we describe a detailed plan to use data from many countries on the share of hens living cage-free to understand the effect of cage-free commitments. We will also consider other factors, like changes in the law and illnesses that kill hens, that could affect how they are housed.
